00001 /*! \file core-drv

00005 
00006 /*! \page core-main OCTEON core driver
00007 
00008  \section cm-sec1 Introduction
00009 
00010  The core component of the OCTEON PCI driver provides a set of API's for OCTEON
00011  core applications
00012  \li to send responses for requests received from the host
00013  \li to send unsolicited data packets to the OCTEON host using OCTEON output queues.
00014  \li to transfer data between host memory and OCTEON local memory using DMA engines.
00015 
00016 The core driver sources can be found at components/driver/core. The core driver
00017 gets compiled as a library which is linked with the core application.
00018 
00019 For an example core application that uses the PCI input, output and DMA engines,
00020 go to applications/pci-core-app/base. The core application is called
00021 <b>cvmcs</b>. It uses the files in pci-core-app/common for initialization and
00022 the files in pci-core-app/test to demonstrate request/response, packet data
00023 transfer via PCI output queue and DMA transfer via the PCI DMA engines.
00024 
00025 
00026 
00027 <br><br>
00028  \section cm-sec2 Input processing in OCTEON cores
00029 
00030     <b>Files:</b> cvm-drv.c
00031 
00032     The core component of OCTEON PCI driver does not have any API's for input
00033  processing. This is because OCTEON treats data arriving from the PCI input
00034 rings in the same way as from any of the other ports. The only exception is
00035 that RAW mode packets include information about the instruction in the work
00036 queue entry.
00037 
00038     OCTEON input ports receive packets from PCI and send it to the
00039 cores for processing in a work queue entry (WQE). The PCI data can be in RAW
00040 mode or packet mode (identified by the WQE structure's 2nd 64-bit word and by
00041 the Instruction Header).
00042 
00043     The PCI Instruction Header (IH) is converted into a Packet Instruction
00044 Header which retain all the fields of the PCI IH except the dlengsz (data
00045 length) and fsz (front data size) fields. In place of these two fields, the
00046 Packet IH has a skip length and Parse Mode fields. Refer to the OCTEON Hardware
00047 Manual for more info on the packet IH format and conversion. The driver
00048 currently uses fixed size front data (16 bytes) and the length field of the WQE
00049 structure gives the total length of packet (including headers).
00050 
00051     A core application that wishes to receive data from the PCI input ports
00052 requests work from OCTEON POW in the same way as it would for other ports. It
00053 can identify data received from the PCI ports by looking at the ipprt field in
00054 WORD1 of the WQE. This field should have a value between 32 and 35 for OCTEON
00055 processors up to CN63xx and 0x100 to 0x11F on OCTEON CN68xx.
00056 
00057 
00058 
00059 <br><br>
00060  \section cm-sec3  Using Output rings from OCTEON cores
00061  <b>Files:</b> cvm-pci-pko.c;  cvm-pci-pko.h
00062 
00063  There are up to 32 PCI output rings available for Core applications to send 
00064 data to the host. Each of these rings is implemented as a descriptor ring in
00065 the host memory. Data is sent out via the PCI Output rings by writing commands
00066 to PKO ports corresponding to the PCI block.  When a command is written
00067 to one of the PKO PCI ports the OCTEON hardware takes care of transferring the
00068 data from the OCTEON memory to the output ring buffers in host memory using PCI
00069 operations. The core driver provides API's that allow core applications to send
00070 data to the PCI output queues. The API's are discussed in detail later in this
00071 chapter.
00072 
00073 
00074 
00075 <br><br>
00076  \section cm-sec4 Sending instruction response from OCTEON cores
00077  <b>Files:</b> cvm-drv-reqresp.c;  cvm-drv-reqresp.h;   cvm-pci-dma.h; cvm-driver-defs.h
00078 
00079 Core applications can send responses via the DMA queues for instructions
00080 received from the host. The response can be send to a single or multiple
00081 locations in the host memory. The core component of the PCI driver provides
00082 several API's that allow core applications to send the response in several
00083 different ways. The API's are discussed in detail later in this chapter.
00084 
00085 
00086 
00087 <br><br>
00088  \section cm-sec5  Data transfer from OCTEON cores
00089  <b>Files: </b> cvm-pci-dma.c;   cvm-pci-dma.h 
00090 
00091  Core applications can transfer data between host memory and OCTEON L2/DRAM
00092  using API's provided by the core PCI driver. The API's takes local buffer
00093 pointers and remote host addresses and uses the PCI DMA engines to transfer data
00094 between the local OCTEON memory and remote host memory.
00095 
00096 
00097 <br><br>
00098  \section pci_init_sec Initialization of the core driver component.
00099  <b>Files: </b> cvm-drv.c;   cvm-driver-defs.h
00100 
00101  This section describes the steps a simple executive application should
00102  take when it needs to use the PCI interface. It also describes the API's
00103  available for use by a core application. Every simple executive application
00104  goes through the following steps:
00105 
00106   \li a) Allocate memory resources for the application globally i.e. one of the
00107      cores does the allocation on behalf of all cores. This includes setting 
00108      up of FPA pools, arena allocation and configuring the IO interfaces.
00109   \li b) Each core then allocates resources it requires like scratchpad location
00110      and memory allocation for local structures.
00111   \li c) Finally, it starts its application specific chores in a loop.
00112 
00113   During step (a), the application should call cvm_drv_init(). This will do
00114   initialization of the PCI ports and also allocate resources for the PCI
00115   input and output interfaces. This actions is done globally by
00116   one of the cores in the application.
00117 
00118   During step (b), the application should call cvm_drv_local_init(). This
00119   reserves scratchpad locations for use by the core driver. These scratchpad
00120   locations serve as storage for memory pointers for driver async allocation
00121   routines. This is done on all the cores which run the application.
00122 
00123   After step (b) and before entering the data processing part in step (c), the 
00124   application should call cvm_drv_start(). This routine sends a packet on PCI
00125   output queue that tells the host that core initialization is complete and PCI
00126   packet transfer can begin. This step is also performed by only one of the
00127   cores running the application.
00128 
00129 
00130 \verbatim
00131    ----------------------------- IMPORTANT -------------------------------
00132    The host driver will NOT send requests to OCTEON until it receives an
00133    indication from the  OCTEON cores. All core applications that want to
00134    use  PCI input ports should call  cvm_drv_start() as the last step in
00135    initialization.
00136 \endverbatim
00137 
00138 
00139 <br><br><br><br>
00140    \section pci_use_sec  PCI core driver API 
00141 <br><br>
00142    <b> Sending response to a request from host </b>
00143 
00144    <b> Important: </b> The OCTEON DMA engine limits each local buffer size to
00145           8184 bytes. This is documented in OCTEON CN38XX PASS3 Errata
00146           as PCI-500.
00147 
00148     <b> Important: </b>: For each DMA command, OCTEON limits the maximum number
00149            of local buffers to 14 and remote pointers to 13.
00150 
00151    \li cvm_drv_pci_instr_response() Use this API if the response header, status
00152           and data are in separate locations in OCTEON memory. The host memory
00153           location is retrieved by the core driver from the instruction front
00154           data (in parameter "front"). Note that this API will reserve 2 local
00155           and 2 remote pointers for the response header & status respectively.
00156 
00157    \li cvm_drv_pci_instr_response_direct() - Use this API if the  the response 
00158           header, status and data are in a single buffer in OCTEON memory.
00159           The host memory location is retrieved by the core driver from the 
00160           instruction front data (in parameter "front").
00161 
00162    \li cvm_dma_send_scatter_response() - Use this API if the response
00163           pointer is a scatter list and not a direct host memory address. Read
00164           the scatter list first by calling cvm_pci_dma_read_scatter_list() and
00165           pass the scatter list along with the local response buffers, response
00166           header and status to this function. The status and response header
00167           are passed as arguments to this function. Note that this API will
00168           reserve 2 local and 2 remote pointers for the response header & status
00169           respectively.
00170 
00171    \li cvm_dma_send_scatter_response_direct() - Use this API if the response
00172           pointer is a scatter list and not a direct host memory address. Read
00173           the scatter list first by calling cvm_pci_dma_read_scatter_list() and
00174           pass the scatter list to this function. The status and response header
00175           are assumed to be part of the response data.
00176 
00177 
00178     All the API's above support blocking and non-blocking calls. The DMA_ACTION
00179     parameter determines the type of call. If the action is DMA_BLOCKING, the
00180     function call does not return till the OCTEON PCI DMA engine indicates that
00181     the DMA is completed. If the action is DMA_NON_BLOCKING, the functions
00182     expects a pointer to a work queue entry (WQE). This WQE will be scheduled by
00183     the DMA engine when the DMA is completed. The application should complete
00184     all DMA post-processing when it receives this WQE.
00185 
00186 
00187     The above functions can be found in cvm-drv-reqresp.c & cvm-drv-reqresp.h.
00188 
00189 
00190 <br><br>
00191     <b> Sending unsolicited data to OCTEON PCI host via Output queues</b>
00192 
00193     <b> Important: </b>: OCTEON limits the maximum data transfer on the PCI
00194        output queue to 65528.
00195 
00196     \li cvm_pko_send_direct() - This API supports local data buffers in a single
00197           buffer or multiple buffers in chained (linked) mode or gather mode.
00198           Use this when the data buffer includes the response header identifying
00199           the data contents.
00200 
00201     \li cvm_pko_send_data()   - This API supports all the data buffer modes 
00202           in cvm_pko_send_direct() but allows the response header to be sent
00203           separately from the data.
00204 
00205     The above functions can be found in cvm-pci-pko.c & cvm-pci-pko.h.
00206 
00207 
00208 <br><br>
00209     <b> Sending data to host memory via DMA engines </b>
00210 
00211     \li cvm_pci_dma_send_direct() - This API provides a low level interface
00212           where the caller is required to specify the DMA command and the local
00213           and remote memory address pointers.
00214 
00215     \li cvm_pci_dma_send_data() -   Use this API to send data to the host memory
00216           via DMA. The DMA command is built by the core driver.
00217 
00218 
00219     The above functions do not have intrinsic support for blocking or
00220     non-blocking operations, though the application can specify a work queue
00221     entry or memory location in the cvm_pci_dma_cmd_t parameters passed to these
00222     routines for PCI DMA completion indication.
00223 
00224     The above functions can be found in cvm-pci-dma.c
00225 
00226 
00227 <br><br>
00228     <b> Receiving data from host memory via DMA engines </b>
00229 
00230     \li cvm_pci_dma_recv_data() -   Use this API to read data from host memory
00231           via DMA. The DMA command is built by the core driver.
00232 
00233     \li cvm_pci_dma_read_scatter_list() - Use this API to read a scatter list
00234           from host memory. The bus address of host memory is passed as a
00235           parameter along with the address of a local buffer where the scatter
00236           list is copied by the DMA engine. This requests supports BLOCKING 
00237           mode where the function does not return till the scatter list is
00238           retrieved, and a NON-BLOCKING mode where the function schedules a
00239           WQE after completion of DMA. The application must provide a WQE when
00240           using the NON-BLOCKING mode and be capable of processing the WQE 
00241           when it is becomes available after completion of DMA.
00242 
00243     The above functions do not have intrinsic support for blocking or
00244     non-blocking operations, though the application can specify a work queue
00245     entry or memory location in the cvm_pci_dma_cmd_t parameters passed to these
00246     routines for PCI DMA completion indication.
00247 
00248     The above functions can be found in cvm-pci-dma.c
00249 
00250 <b>NOTE:</b>  Please refer to the README.txt at OCTEON-SDK/components/driver for compilation instructions.
00251 
00252  */
